MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Government Policy on Aer Lingus/Aerlínte

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Transport in view of public concern about the financing of Aer Lingus and preservation of existing jobs therein, if he will make a statement on the Government's policy for financing the continued operation of the North Atlantic route.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Transport (Mr. Wilson) John P. Wilson
Speaker.P: Following a detailed examination of the financial position of Aer Lingus/Aerlínte, with particular reference to the losses at present being incurred on the companies' transatlantic services, the Government proposes to increase the authorised share capital of Aerlínte by £60 million and to extend by £75 million the limit on the amount of the air companies State-guaranteed borrowing. I intend to introduce the necessary legislation early in the next session.

The Government have decided to subscribe £10 million by way of additional equity investment in Aerlínte in the current financial year and will consider the question of further equity investment in the context of the 1983 Public Capital Programme.

On receipt of the appeals officer's decision he will be notified of the outcome as soon as possible.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: The person concerned originally claimed deserted wife's allowance on 28 July 1976 but her claim was refused on the grounds that she was under 40 years of age and had no qualified child. She re-applied on 10 April 1978 and, as she then had a qualified child, the allowance was awarded at the maximum appropriate rate from 13 April 1978, the Thursday following the date of application. Payment of the allowance continued up to 7 September 1978 when she resumed employment. As her means derived from earnings from this employment exceeded the statutory limit the allowance was terminated from that date.

MainHeading.P: On 4 June 1982 the claimant notified the Department that she wished to claim deserted wife's benefit. The question of her entitlement to the benefit had, however, already been investigated in 1978 and it was decided that she was not entitled to payment on either her own or her husband's insurance prior to the date of desertion. She was notified to this effect at the time. An inspector will call on her at an early date to investigate her means with a view to restoring payment of deserted wife's allowance if her circumstances so warrant.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Dublin Barracks Married Quarters.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gregory-Independent Mr. Gregory-Independent

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. Power) Patrick Power
Speaker.P: The provision of housing is primarily a matter for the local authorities and married soldiers have an equal claim on such housing with other members of the community in the same category. Representations have been made by my Department to Dublin Corporation on behalf of the occupants of the married quarters at Arbour Hill who have applied to the corporation for re-housing.

As the quarters at Arbour Hill become vacant they will not be re-allocated except in so far as may be necessary to facilitate the evacuation of a particular block of quarters. It is proposed to demolish each block of quarters as it becomes vacant.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry when he proposes to employ more people in South Tipperary to improve and develop afforestation there.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Fisheries and Forestry (Mr. Daly) Brendan Daly
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Fisheries and Forestry (Mr. Daly)
Speaker.P: With the permission of the Ceann Comhairle, I propose to take Questions Nos. 537 and 538 together.

While I fully subscribe to the objectives of increasing employment and production, the funds allocated to my Department in the current year unfortunately preclude any increases in the work force in the areas referred to or indeed in forestry generally. However, I intend to keep the matter under constant review in the light of the prevailing financial circumatances.

I am pleased to say that a new American-owned factory is under construction at Clonmel for the manufacture of medium density fibreboard using pulpwood from Irish forests. The project is expected to commence operations in mid-1983 and at full production will provide some 450 jobs.
